docs.lead_paragraph: The door to the global bond market has opened a crack, and Argentina and some Latin American companies are starting to slip through. Their success in borrowing money in the last few weeks is a sign that the financial crisis that seemed so severe in emerging markets and elsewhere just two months ago is easing. This reservoir of needed cash had been all but closed to borrowers from emerging markets ever since Russia effectively defaulted on its debt in mid-August. With the heat of the world financial crisis turned up to white hot, investors were suddenly demanding a crippling 20 percent return for lending in these economically troubled nations.

headline.main: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Opening Door Policy; Latin America Leads Way in Emerging Markets' Revival

docs.snippet: The door to the global bond market has opened a crack, and Argentina and some Latin American companies are starting to slip through. Their success in borrowing money in the last few weeks is a sign that the financial crisis that seemed so severe in...

docs.lead_paragraph: The state takeover of the H.I.P. Health Plan of New Jersey was complicated today by proceedings in a Federal bankruptcy court in Delaware. Judge Joseph J. Farnan Jr. of that court issued a temporary restraining order today blocking the state takeover of H.I.P. The order also blocked H.I.P from breaking its contract with Pinnacle Health Enterprises, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in the Delaware court. The judge said the loss of the contract would interfere with Pinnacle's efforts to begin reorganization.

headline.main: Takeover of Troubled H.M.O. Complicated by Federal Court

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: When I read articles like your Nov. 17 news article about the retreat by Oxford Health Plans from the Medicare supplement business, I wonder why we resist national health insurance, which would cover all people regardless of age or condition.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a merger that would create one of the biggest providers of housing and health care services for retirees in the United States, the American Retirement Corporation has agreed to acquire Assisted Living Concepts Inc. in a stock swap worth $272 million. American Retirement would also assume $228 million of Assisted Living debt. Combined, the companies could accommodate more than 18,300 residents in 24 states. American Retirement, based in Nashville, is to exchange 0.85 share of its stock for each share of Assisted Living. The ratio values Assisted Living at $14.66 a share. Shares of Assisted Living, based in Portland, Ore., were down 37.5 cents yesterday at $12.875, and American Retirement's stock fell $1 a share, to $16.25.

headline.main: AMERICAN RETIREMENT IN STOCK SWAP FOR ASSISTED LIVING

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Scrambling for Coverage'' (news article, Nov. 17): In 1992, when Bill Clinton first ran on a platform of health care for everyone, every imaginable obstacle was thrown into the path of any possible plan. To top it off, we were threatened with the specter of ''losing the right to choose our own doctor.''

headline.main: Managed Care Has Failed Us All

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: No managed-care organization can provide adequate care when the oldest and sickest use up 75 percent of the available money (news article, Nov. 17). The solution is to spread the risk pool to include everyone and to provide a defined benefit package to each subscriber. Spreading costs across the spectrum of possible participants would drastically lower the unit cost for each member and make health care affordable for everyone.

headline.main: Managed Care Has Failed Us All

docs.lead_paragraph: Efforts to shore up the sagging finances of New Jersey's fourth-largest health maintenance organization took a bitter public turn today when the organization, H.I.P. Health Plan of New Jersey, broke its contract with the medical provider it hired 18 months ago. That provider then filed for bankruptcy protection. The actions abruptly ended nearly two weeks of secret negotiations among H.I.P., the medical provider it hired, Pinnacle Health Enterprises, whose parent company is the PHP Healthcare Corporation of Reston, Va., and state regulators. PHP also filed for bankruptcy protection.

headline.main: A Troubled H.M.O. Agrees To Supervision by the State

docs.abstract: HIP Health Plan of New Jersey, state's fourth-largest health maintenance organization, breaks its contract with Pinnacle Health Enterprises, medical provider it hired 18 months ago; Pinnacle and its parent company, PHP Healthcare Corp, then file for bankruptcy protection; actions end nearly two weeks of secret negotiations among HIP, Pinnacle and state regulators aimed at forestalling threatened state takeover of plan, which serves 194,000 people (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a major setback to ABC's off-camera television workers, a Federal official dismissed their union's unfair labor practices complaint against the network yesterday, declaring the company's 17-day-old lockout of 2,200 workers legal. The ruling by the National Labor Relations Board's regional director for New York City came one day after ABC obtained a court order in Los Angeles preventing union pickets from interfering with the network's news coverage. The two sides planned to return to the bargaining table today for the first time in more than six weeks, meeting with Federal mediators in Iselin, N.J.

headline.main: Labor Board Backs ABC in Lockout of Strikers

docs.abstract: National Labor Relations Board regional director, Daniel Silverman, dismisses complaint by ABC's off-camera television workers about unfair labor practices; says ABC's 17-day-old lockout of 2,200 workers is legal (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Sun Lilin emerged from Beijing Children's Hospital, her pockets bulged with bottles of syrup and her hands juggled a tower of boxes containing powders and pills. She had taken her 5-year-old daughter to the clinic with a cough. She left with two Chinese cold syrups, a potent broad-spectrum antibiotic, an inhaler and a little round device that jets powdered medicine into the lungs.

headline.main: West's Medicine Is Raising Bills For China's Sick

docs.abstract: Imported Western pharmaceuticals have taken China by storm, straining pocketbooks as they hold out promises of cure; Western drug companies have been aggressively courting China's doctors and hospitals not only with new pills, but also with gifts, money and even kickbacks, practices that are banned in US; their goal: to gain access to China's 1.2 billion potentially ailing citizens, most with seemingly unshakable belief in curative power of name-brand Western pills; doctors say that Western medicines and medical equipment have contributed to medical costs that are rising 35 percent a year in China; photo (M)
